title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
I first heard of constructed languages, or conlangs, when I heard of Esperanto. I did my research and found out that Esperanto is a terrible conlang for reaching its purpose, which was to promote world peace, since it was so Eurocentric. I also heard of Toki Pona, which combines many different languages, and is very simple due to its limited vocabulary. I wanted to make my own language, which is completely different from any other language, but has very simple grammar and vocabulary.

Limit is my first conlang, and the majority of it was made before I knew any linguistics, which makes it more natural and less overthought than my later conlangs.

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Pronunciation and Alphabet
Limit is written in Roman characters (for now, that is; we will introduce the real writing system later), but there are some rules to how the script works.
Consonants are mostly lowercase, with the only exception being the letter â€œLâ€, which is always capitalized. Each consonant is a short sound. Short vowel sounds are lowercase, while long vowel sounds are uppercase. The language is very phonetic; the pronunciation is exactly what is written. There are no silent letters.
Examples for how to write and pronounce vowels:
1. A short â€œOâ€ like in the word â€œdogâ€ would be lowercase.
2. A long â€œAâ€ like in the word â€œcakeâ€ would be uppercase.






Note



A quick note: The letter â€œUâ€ (capital, which means long) does not contain a â€œyâ€ sound in its pronunciation. It sounds like the oâ€™s in the word â€œfoodâ€ rather than the u in the word â€œuniversityâ€.
There are some vowel and consonant sounds, of course, that cannot be produced with just the Roman alphabet. Therefore, the Limit alphabet contains some extra characters as well.



Extra vowel sounds

â€œ%â€ sounds like â€œooâ€ in the word â€œbookâ€.

â€œ@â€ sounds like â€œowâ€ like in the word â€œnowâ€.

â€œÎ±â€ sounds like â€œahâ€ like in the word â€œdramaâ€

â€œ&â€ sounds like â€œoiâ€ like in the word â€œboyâ€.

â€œ*â€ sounds like â€œerâ€ like in the word â€œsingerâ€.

â€œ^â€ sounds like â€œonâ€ like in the word â€œbonâ€ in French (used for foreign loanwords).



Extra consonant sounds

â€œ#â€ sounds like â€œzhâ€, like in the s in â€œmeasureâ€.

â€œ~â€ sounds like â€œthâ€, like in the word â€œthinkâ€.

â€œÎ²â€ sounds like the n in â€œsongâ€.

â€œ!â€ sounds like â€œshâ€, like in the word â€œshookâ€.



Other adjustments to the alphabet

To make the â€œarâ€ or â€œorâ€ sound, take â€œÎ±â€ or â€œOâ€ and add â€œ*â€.

The letter â€œcâ€ is removed as its sound can be made from either â€œkâ€ or â€œsâ€.

The letter â€œgâ€ only can sound like the g in â€œgrayâ€, and NOT sound like a j, like in â€œgiraffeâ€.

The letter â€œjâ€ is removed as any sound with a â€œjâ€ can be made from â€œd#â€.

The letter â€œqâ€ is removed as any â€œquâ€ sound can be made with â€œkwâ€ instead. â€œuâ€, however, is still perfectly safe as it is important for various vowel sounds.

The letter â€œxâ€ is removed as any sound with an â€œxâ€ can be made from either â€œksâ€ or â€œzâ€.

Slashes indicate that some specific words are grouped together.

One last thing: Limit is pronounced in either an Indian or an American accent, except with the new pronunciation rules now given.

Pronouns and Verbs
If you have a pronoun and a verb, you have a simple sentence, so let us start here in our journey to learn real Limit words. There is no gender or verb conjugation for each pronoun in Limit, so this should be simple.

Limit

To make any of these pronouns formal, just add the prefix â€œyUâ€.
To make any of these pronouns insulting, just add the prefix â€œyoLâ€. If you are talking directly to someone, add the suffix â€œ*â€ or â€œp*â€ for â€œdIdâ€ and â€œdIâ€ respectively.


Verbs
Present tense: Suffix â€œULâ€
Past tense: Suffix â€œUzâ€
Future tense: Suffix â€œUkâ€
To make something infinitive, remove the Uz/UL/Uk and add the suffix â€œUpâ€.
To negate a verb, add the suffix â€œO#Uâ€ or â€œ#Uâ€ (depending on if it ends in a vowel or consonant) at the very end of the word.

Example

To eat is â€œbrikUpâ€.

â€œI did not eatâ€ would be â€œLI brikUzO#Uâ€.

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Syntax
Here are some rules for sentence structure:

The order of a declarative sentence is Subject Object Verb.

Adjectives always come after nouns, attached by a slash, without spaces.

Articles come after nouns as well, also attached by a slash without spaces.

If there is an article and an adjective, the adjective comes after the article, and the adjective and the article are combined with slashes as well.

Adverbs come before the verb or adjective that they modify, with a backslash with no spaces. If they modify an adjective, then it goes before the noun.

There is no distinction between proper and common nouns.

Prepositions work the same way as in English.

Objects, like in English, do not have to just be nouns but also any verb phrase that acts as a noun. Predicate adjectives and predicate nominatives also count as objects.

Prepositional phrases (like â€œin the houseâ€) count as objects as well.

Indirect objects come right before direct objects.

Indirect objects have the suffix â€œbâ€, or â€œObâ€ if the word ends in a consonant.

Predicate adjectives would actually be adverbs, as they modify the word â€œbLIvUpâ€.
Examples:
Write â€œI like to eatâ€ in Limit syntax and spelling.
I tU Et LIk
Write â€œI give you a green boxâ€ in Limit syntax and spelling.
I yUhU boks/A/grEn giv

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Inflections
To inflect a word ending in O, make the final consonant of the inflection thing voiceless. For example, the plural of â€œriLmOâ€ (monkey) will be â€œriLmOtâ€ instead of â€œriLmOdâ€ (riLmOd is not a real word for that reason). And, the possessive of â€œriLmOâ€ will be â€œriLmOfâ€ instead of â€œriLmOvâ€. Likewise, youâ€™d say â€œriLmOkEâ€ instead of â€œriLmOgEâ€, â€œriLmOpUâ€ instead of â€œriLmObUâ€, and â€œriLmOsAâ€ instead of â€œriLmOzAâ€.

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Punctuation
Commas are written as â€œ~â€.
Periods are written as â€œ-â€.
Quotation marks are written as â€œ+â€ on either end of the quote.
Question marks are just a word, that being â€œLEâ€.

How to use a possessive noun for a person (for example, â€œThat is Bobâ€™sâ€):
Add â€œOvâ€ to the end of their name if it ends in a consonant, otherwise add â€œvâ€.
If the noun it modifies is plural, then add â€œOdâ€ or â€œdâ€.

My books are big = â€œzO*pOd/LIvOd Lib blivULâ€

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Adjectives

Articles
The (singular): vU
The (plural): vUd
Indefinite articles are implied if there is no article.
Remember, the articles go after the noun and before another adjective, connected with a slash.


Demonstratives
This: #%t
That: #at
Those: #atOd
These: #%tOd
Demonstratives go after the noun and before another adjective, connected with a slash, just like articles. If they are pronouns, then just treat them as pronouns instead.


Plurals
Adjectives have to agree with their noun in number. If the noun is singular, the adjectives will also be singular, and if the noun is plural, the adjectives will also be plural. To make a noun or an adjective plural, add a â€œdâ€ if it ends in a vowel, and add an â€œOdâ€ if it ends in a consonant.
Adjective phrases also go after the noun, and just the first word of the adjective phrase will be combined with a slash to the noun.
There will also be a slash after the last word, if the adjective phrase is more than a single word.

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Adverbs
To turn an adjective into an adverb, add the prefix â€œ.@â€.
This is analogous to adding an â€œlyâ€ at the end in English.
Adverbs go right before the adjective, verb, or adverb that they modify.
Example:
The word for â€œrealâ€ is â€œgOhOâ€, which means the word for â€œreallyâ€ is â€œ.@gOhOâ€.
I am really good = â€œLI .@gOhO\LimitO#U blivULâ€

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Numbers
Base 10 is used, like normal.
One shorthand is implemented; whenever there is a 1 followed by a 0, it is written as Î¸.
Numbers are written as normal Arabic numerals, but obviously they are said differently.
0: â€œfAâ€
1: â€œhÎ±â€
2: â€œrOâ€
3: â€œd#Uâ€
4: â€œyAâ€
5: â€œ.aâ€
6: â€œbrUâ€
7: â€œ,Oâ€
8: â€œweâ€
9: â€œgIâ€
To get more numbers, you do the following:
Write each digit in the bigger number as the sum of each digit times a power of 10. For example, 243 would be 2*102+4*101+3*10^0.
You may know that â€œtime ten to the power ofâ€ can also be written as â€œEâ€. In Limit, the symbol for this is â€œ$â€, pronounced â€œsigmÎ±â€. Fun fact: this word also means â€œandâ€.
You would write the each place value from highest exponent to lowest.
Instead of saying plus, you would just combine each term with a slash.
Units digits do not need to be written as a$0, just a.
Back to the example of 243, in Limit you would say this as:
2$2/4\(1/3, and pronounce this as rO\)rO/yA$hÎ±/jU, and remember that $ is pronounced as sigmÎ±.
For negative numbers, add the suffix â€œyOâ€.
For ordinal numbers, add the suffix â€œhOâ€, after the â€œyOâ€ if it is there.
For fractions, just use the postposition for â€œinâ€, which is the suffix â€œkrAâ€ or â€œOkrAâ€. There will be a space after that.
You can also just list each digit, but then you must indicate the decimal point when applicable, which is pronounced as â€œ%ndâ€ and is written as â€œ*â€.
Example:
You would say â€œ31.4thâ€ as â€œjU\(hÎ±/hÎ±/yA\)hÎ±yOhOâ€.

Questions
Just say the equivalent declarative sentence, then add â€œLE-â€ (which means question mark) to the end.
Phrasing Examples:
â€œWhich one do you like?â€ -> â€œYou one/which like LE-â€
â€œHow are you?â€ -> â€œYou how are LE-â€

text:
Commands
State the equivalent in a future tense declarative sentence, and speak in 2nd person. Use the word for please, â€œhokâ€, at the end of the sentence, after the verb.
Phrasing Examples:
â€œGo to bed.â€ -> â€œYou will to bed go hok-â€
Also, instead of saying â€œhokâ€, you can say â€œbOLOdOwO#Oâ€, which is short for â€œbU LI dI wopLUkO#Uâ€, which means something along the lines of â€œor I will kill youâ€.
Fun fact: the word â€œhokâ€ is actually a loanword from Proto-Zorbbbb.

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Prepositions
First, be sure to note that Limit uses a suffix for prepositions (so they are actually postpositions) like â€œinâ€, â€œatâ€, â€œduringâ€, â€œofâ€, etc; this means anything that gives the position or time, not something that is being headed towards. This suffix is â€œgEâ€, or â€œOgEâ€, depending on if the word ends in a vowel or consonant.
There is also a suffix for something you are heading to. This includes words such as â€œbeforeâ€, â€œtoâ€, or â€œforâ€. The suffix is â€œbUâ€, or â€œObUâ€, depending on if the word ends in a vowel or consonant.
Finally, for something you are coming from, such as â€œfromâ€, â€œafterâ€, or â€œpastâ€, the suffix will be either â€œzAâ€ or â€œOzAâ€.

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
General Rule of Affixes
If the word ends in a consonant, and the suffix starts with a consonant, then put an â€œOâ€ between them.
If the word ends in a vowel and the suffix starts with a consonant, or the other way around, then there is no need for an extra â€œOâ€.
This same intuition is to be applied to prefixes.

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Conjunctions
The conjunctions (subordinating and coordinating, and also including relative pronouns) are:

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Abbreviations
Just like how thereâ€™s â€œts pmoâ€ for [censored], in Limit there are abbreviations too. Except, between consonants, you must add a â€œ@â€. For example, bU LI dI wopLUkO#U becomes bOLOdOwO#O. Also, negation affixes are important enough to count as their own word, so just put #O at the end if it is negated, like in this one.

title: Limit riLmOtOpU (Limit For Monkeys)
text:
Comparatives and Superlatives
How you would phrase this:
[Subject] [Person, indirect form] [Attribute, locative form] [Win/Lose].
The [Person, indirect form] can be removed if the sentence is superlative.
Note that the indirect form and the locative form both have a postpositional ending, so it may be confusing.
The attribute must be a verb. Nouns, adjectives, and adverbs must be reworded.

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text: This is a series of blogs about linguistics. Check out my ones about math, physics, and AI as well!

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text:
Introduction
Have you ever wondered how kids sing their â€œabcâ€™sâ€ in different places? In some places, kids sing their â€œalpha beta gammaâ€™sâ€ or their â€œalif baa jiimâ€™sâ€, which are pretty similar to our own. In some places, kids recite their â€œka kha ga gha ngaâ€™sâ€, quite different from our own. Yet in other places, such a song about their â€œalphabetâ€ would be physically impossible, with kids thinking this is a preposterous and cruel joke. All of these are tricks for remembering letters, which are part of writing systems. Writing systems are also known as orthographies. You already know at least one - the Latin alphabet, which youâ€™re reading right now. Hereâ€™s an overview of how all the different writing systems work.

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text:
Phonetic Orthographies
In phonetic writing systems, symbols are written based on sound. For example, in the Latin alphabet, the word â€œcatâ€ is written with a â€œcâ€ for the â€œcâ€ sound, â€œaâ€ for the â€œaâ€ sound, and â€œtâ€ for the â€œtâ€ sound. Of course, itâ€™s not always one-to-one, or even consistent, in English itself (cough cough, â€œcoughâ€), but the main point still stands - itâ€™s based on sound. In our language, you wouldnâ€™t draw an image of a cat to represent a cat, youâ€™d just write â€œcatâ€ based on the sounds of the word. Here are the types of phonetic writing systems:

Alphabets
Alphabets work by having symbols for vowels and consonants, and theyâ€™re just written without really being treated as separate phonemes. These are arguably the simplest. Apart from the Latin alphabet, some others are Cyrillic, Greek, IPA, Georgian, Armenian, etc. Koreanâ€™s writing system, Hangeul, is kind of like an alphabet because it writes out its vowels and consonants, but it arranges each syllable into its own block. For example, the characters for â€œbaâ€ would be ë°”, but the characters for â€œboâ€ would be ë³´. Furthermore, the characters for â€œbolâ€ would be ë³¼. The word alphabet comes from the first to letters of Greek, alpha and beta.


Abjads
Most alphabets evolved from abjads. Abjads are like alphabets, except usually, most of the vowels arenâ€™t written, and instead inferred from context. Only long vowels are written. Sometimes, for clarity, the short vowels may be written in with diacritics. For example, in the Quran, even though the Arabic script is an abjad, all the vowels were written so that there arenâ€™t any misinterpretations. The word â€œabjadâ€ comes from the first sounds of the four letters of the Arabic script, â€œaâ€, â€œbâ€, â€œjâ€, and â€œdâ€, which is cognate with Greekâ€™s â€œalphaâ€, â€œbetaâ€, â€œgammaâ€, â€œdeltaâ€.
The most prominent example of abjads are the orthographies of Semitic languages, which it works well for due to their triconsonantal root system, where consonants carry the meaning and vowels just modify the word. Hwvr, f y d ths n nglsh, t wll b prtt mssd p nd nt t ll ntllgbl.


Syllabaries
In syllabaries, each symbol is a syllable, usually a pair of consonant and vowel. These work well for languages that donâ€™t have crazy consonant clusters, like Japanese and Cherokee. However, if a language has a lot of possible syllables due to its large phonology, then there would be way too many symbols. 


Abugidas
Abugidas, in my opinion, are by far the coolest type of phonetic orthography. How it works is that if you write a consonant on its own, it comes with a vowel after it. For example, the /k/ sound in Devanagari, à¤•, is actually pronounced /kÉ™/ because without altering the consonant, it comes with an /É™/ sound. To make it a different vowel, you add a diacritic. So, /ke/ would be à¤•à¥‡. And, to make it just /k/ with no vowel, you make it à¤•à¥. The most popular abugidas are from India, including Devanagiri, Tamil, Bengali, etc. However, the word â€œabugidaâ€ comes from the Geâ€™ez script from Ethiopia, where the first four letters are â€œaâ€, â€œbuâ€, â€œgiâ€, and â€œdaâ€ (and this arrangement is cognate with Greekâ€™s â€œalphaâ€, â€œbetaâ€, â€œgammaâ€, â€œdeltaâ€, just like with the word â€œAbjadâ€). Another notable abugida, apart from Indian scripts, Southeast Asian scripts, and the Geâ€™ez script, is the Cree script. For changing the vowel, Cree doesnâ€™t actually add a diacritic, but instead modifies the consonant through rotations. Cree is actually partially inspired by Devanagiri.

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text:
Semantic Orthographies
Instead of writing symbols based on sound, some languages have orthographies where symbols are based on meaning.

Logographies
The most common type of semantic writing system is a logography, and the most famous type of logography is Hanzi from Sinitic languages, which is also what Japaneseâ€™s Kanji is based on. For example, look at the symbol for â€œyiâ€ in Mandarin or â€œichiâ€ in Japanese, which means â€œoneâ€: â€œä¸€â€ Now, for â€œerâ€ in Mandarin or â€œniâ€ in Japanese, which means â€œtwoâ€: â€œäºŒâ€ So, sometimes, the symbol looks like what it means. However, sometimes, it can be more complicated than that. In Mandarin, each symbol is generally one syllable as well, and sometimes symbols are made based on their relation with other semantic meanings, so you can build up symbols from smaller symbols. For example, the symbol for â€œforestâ€ is: æ£® while the symbol for â€œtreeâ€ is: æœ¨ Also, symbols whose words sound similar can also be used for clarification. Egyptian hieroglyphs were part logography. Some symbols worked just like Chinese, and others evolved into more of a syllabary or abjad.


Pictographies
Pictographies are kind of like logographies, except that itâ€™s much more literal. Unlike Hanzi, where a lot of characters are derived from abstract connections, pictographies are literal depictions. This is likely where writing started first. An example is the Mayan script, where a lot of it was pictographic, but other symbols evolved into being logographic or syllabic. Also, even emojis are largely pictographic. However, pictographs, like logographs, still just represent words. 


Ideographies
Ideographies are another type of semantic orthography, where an idea or a concept is directly written, without being tied to a specific sound. For example, some street signs symbols that donâ€™t have words but rather symbols, some of the more ancient Hanzi initially, or even some of the more abstract emojis as well are ideographies.

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text:
Evolution of writing
Many writing systems evolved from Egyptian hieroglyphs, to become primarily alphabets, abjads, or even abugidas. This is primarily in Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa, where Egypt indirectly influenced. For example, the European alphabets evolved from Ancient Greekâ€™s alphabet (Latin through the Etruscan alphabet, which in turn came from the Ancient Greek alphabet), which evolved from Phoenecianâ€™s abjad, which evolved from Egyptian hieroglyphs. Also, the Semitic abjads evolved from Phoenicianâ€™s abjad too. The Semitic languages are written from right to left, because it chose a direction to write from Phoenecian, which alternated. Ancient Greek also initially alternated directions line by line, but then chose to stick with only left to right, which all the European languages are written with now.
In India, as well as some parts of Southeast Asia, including Myanmar, Laos, and Thailand, the orthography (all abugidas) of those languages evolved from the Brahmi script, which was an abugida. Itâ€™s not certain where the Brahmi script is from, though itâ€™s suggested to come from Egyptian hieroglyphs too, but it could also be an artificially created script that evolved naturally.



An example of Brahmi script found on The Iron Pillar in Qutub Minar, New Delhi, source








Cool fact to bore your friends with and be called a nerd!!!



The Brahmi script was initially all straight lines and sharp angles. In South India, Southeast Asia, and Sri Lanka, the letters look more curvy, because they were written on leaves, so sharp turns and straight lines would tear the leaves. However, in North India, the letters can be more angular and sharp, but still also some curves, because they were written on both leaves and stone.


In China and Japan, the characters are derived from the Ancient Chinese logographic characters. In Japan, there are three writing systems. Two are syllabaries derived from Chinese, and the other is the normal Chinese logography.
In both Koreas, Hangeul is used. Hangeul is an artificially created script that was made to address the high percentage of illiteracy, due to the fact that Chinese characters were way to hard for the common people to learn. However, Hangeul was designed to be very simple.
The Cherokee syllabary was made after one Native American looked at the European colonizersâ€™ writing and tried to mimic the symbols to make a writing system for Cherokee. Heâ€™d seen both the Latin and Cyrillic scripts. However, the symbols in Cherokee that look similar to the European writing make completely different sounds, as he only knew the shape of the symbols, not what sound they made.

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text:
How Sounds Work
At first, the question of â€œhow do sounds workâ€ may seem dumb - you just vibrate your vocal cords, right? However, itâ€™s more complicated than that. When you were a baby, you were as educated as a linguistics major in that you were able to identify how different sounds are made from observing peopleâ€™s mouths. Now, itâ€™s more difficult to do so, and you may struggle - unless, of course, youâ€™re a baby reading this, and in that case, you should become incredibly famous and win a world record if you havenâ€™t already.
In kindergarten, you may have learned that sounds are classified as vowels and consonants, and that sounds are known as phonemes. However, Iâ€™ll talk about vowels later. Right now, letâ€™s do consonants. In short, the two main parameters that control how a consonant is made are â€œplace of articulationâ€ and â€œmanner of articulationâ€.

Place of Articulation
Place of articulation is essentially where in your mouth a sound is being made, whether it be deep in the throat (Iâ€™m looking at you, certain language primarily spoken in a country that borders Belgium, Germany, Luxembourg, Spain, Andorra, Monaco, Brazil, Suriname, and Italy) or front in the lips (like at the end of â€œdumbâ€). From deepest in the throat to closest in the lips, the most commonly referred to categories include glottal, pharyngeal, uvular, velar, retroflex, palatal, alveolar, dental, labiodental, and bilabial.


Manner of Articulation
Manner of articulation is how the sound is actually made. For example, there is a difference between â€œboronâ€ and â€œmoronâ€, even though both /b/ and /m/ are both â€œbilabialâ€ sounds (one of the places of articulation mentioned above). Such manners of articulation include: Fricatives (blowing air, like in the â€œsssssâ€ sound in â€œsnakeâ€); Plosives (stopping the sound, like how in â€œdartâ€, pronouncing both the /d/ and /t/ canâ€™t really be continued); Nasals (where air comes out of your â€œnnnnn-nostrilsâ€); Trills (where a sound is like a plosive but gets rolled, like the Spanish rolled r in â€œperroâ€); Clicks (air is sucked in instead of pushed out, but unfortunately these cool sounds donâ€™t exist in English, so I canâ€™t provide an example you know how to pronounce. However, the name of the language Xhosa, (in)famous for having a lot of clicks, has a click in its name when not butchered as /kshosa/); and more.


More
Another important parameter is voicedness. Voicedness is just if the vocal cords are vibrating while the sound is being made. To understand this, look at /s/ and /z/, or /k/ and /g/ (as an exercise, find the voiceless version of /b/). In most languages, this has a really important distinction. For example, take â€œtieâ€ and â€œdieâ€. However, we usually just include this within manner of articulation, because we canâ€™t put 3D charts on the iPad screen your face is glued to.
Consonants are classified in other ways than just the two (or three) parameters, though. For example, there are pulmonic and non-pulmonic consonants. This just means if the sound is normal or a freak that doesnâ€™t use air coming from the lungs. The only non-pulmonic consonants are implosives, ejectives, and clicks, and the rest are generally pulmonic. There is also sonorance or obstruence. Sonorance means the vocal tract is pretty open, like a vowel. As a result, most sonorants, which include nasals, approximants, and liquids, tend to be voiced. Obstruence means there is some friction or turbulence which make the sounds more easily voiceless and are noisier.
Additionally, there are more factors that can alter a consonant. If you know Hindi, for example, you know how aspiration - putting extra air after a consonant - can impact a word and does matter, like in the words â€œà¤ªà¤²â€ (pronounced like â€œpalâ€, meaning â€œmomentâ€) and â€œà¤«à¤²â€ (pronounced like â€œphalâ€, meaning â€œfruitâ€). In Russian, palatalization - making the consonant more like a palatal sound, which basically just makes it sound like â€œyâ€ sound is at the end - is a very important factor too, with the words â€œĞ¼Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒâ€ (pronounced like â€œmatyâ€ with the y being as in â€œyoâ€ and not â€œcornyâ€) meaning â€œmotherâ€ but â€œĞ¼Ğ°Ñ‚â€ (pronounced like â€œmatâ€) meaning a swear word. Gemination - making a consonant pronounced for longer - is important in Finnish, because â€œtapaâ€ means â€œwayâ€ or â€œmannerâ€, but â€œtappaâ€ means â€œkillâ€.


Vowels
Even in vowels, two main parameters affect how a vowel is made. While vowels are not that interesting in my opinion, they are definitely required, because without them youâ€™d be speaking either gibberish or Polish. Vowels tend to be voiced because they are sonorant and made by vibrating the vocal cords.
The parameters are frontness (deep in the throat or front in the mouth) and closedness (is mouth open or closed). A third binary parameter is there, roundedness, which is if your mouth is shaped like a circle or not. For example, the /i/ sound is a closed front unrounded vowel.
There are many more variations to vowels that can be made now. For example, tone is a big factor in Mandarin. ç³– (tÃ¡ng) means sugar, but æ±¤ (tÄng) means soup. Nasality (how much air comes out of the nostrils) is important in Fr*nch, as â€œaâ€ means â€œhasâ€ but â€œanâ€ means â€œyearâ€. Rhoticity (how much the vowel sounds r-colored) makes the word â€œorâ€ sound American when rhotic, but British when you only pronounce it like /o/. Vowels can also have creaky or breathy voice (basically making it sound like a sheep or a zombie, respectively).

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text:
The IPA
Now that you know how sounds are made, letâ€™s see how ğš—Ì¶ğšÌ¶ğš›Ì¶ğšÌ¶ğšœÌ¶ linguists actually write them. They made a chart called the International Phonetic Alphabet where each letter is consistent and makes the same sound all the time, because they are defined using the specific terms we talked about, like voiceless geminated bilabial trill (basically just horse noises). The IPA is kind of like the Periodic Table of linguistics. You may have noticed that throughout this article Iâ€™ve used slashes to refer to sounds. That was not just something random I did because a monkey walked on my keyboard one time and then I stuck with it - this is actually the notation of referencing IPA sounds.
Many letters are just like in English. For example, why donâ€™t you take a random guess at how /p/, /h/, /v/, /z/, /m/, /Éª/ and /t/ are pronounced? Yes! They are pronounced like â€œpâ€, â€œhâ€, â€œvâ€, â€œzâ€, â€œmâ€, â€œÉªâ€ and â€œtâ€! BUT NOT LIKE â€œpeaâ€, â€œaichâ€, â€œveeâ€, â€œzeeâ€, â€œemâ€, â€œeyeâ€, and â€œteaâ€ - you need to hop off elementary school English if you said that. And if you said â€œmomentumâ€, â€œPlanckâ€™s constantâ€, â€œvelocityâ€, â€œheight coordinateâ€, â€œmassâ€, â€œcurrentâ€, and â€œtimeâ€, hop off physics!
However, there are some tricky ones too that are designed to deceive you. For example, what sounds do you think /j/, /x/, /É‘/, /r/, /q/, /c/, and /Ê”/ make? No, it is not â€œjayâ€, â€œeksâ€, â€œaeyâ€, â€œarâ€, â€œkyooâ€, â€œseeâ€, and â€œhmmm?â€, or â€œimpulseâ€, â€œpositionâ€, â€œaccelerationâ€, â€œradiusâ€, â€œchargeâ€, â€œspeed of lightâ€, and â€œhmmm?â€. Instead, they make the voiced palatal approximant, voiceless velar fricative, unrounded open back vowel, voiced alveolar trill, voiceless uvular stop, voiceless palatal stop, and the glottal stop (glottal stop doesnâ€™t have a voiced version, because itâ€™s just the break between â€œuhâ€ and â€œohâ€ in â€œuh-ohâ€).
Weâ€™re not done. Thereâ€™s even Greek letters, which somehow we can never evade, regardless of the subject. /É¸/, /Î¸/, /Ê/, /É¤/, and /ÊŠ/ are not phi, theta, lambda, gamma, and upside-down omega, but instead voiceless bilabial fricative, voiceless alveolar fricative, voiced palatal lateral approximant, back close-mid unrounded vowel, and then this random vowel that doesnâ€™t know where it belongs. Phew. That torture is over. Or is it?
We still have the diacritics to go over, but this time I wonâ€™t subject you to the pain of looking at every diacritic. Instead, Iâ€™ll just say that the diacritics can alter a sound to fit any of the variations for consonants and vowels I talked about earlier, such as nasality, gemination, voiceless, tone, and more.
To see the visual representation of the IPA, look here. Each language has its phonology written, by placing the accurate symbols of all of its phonemes. For example, see the phonology of Fr*nch.

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text:
To Be Continued
Phonemes, used by the IPA, are the building blocks of morphemes, which are the building blocks of words, sentences, and languages. However, I want to specify that phonemes are not usually connected to morphemes, as sound and meaning are generally independent. To talk about meaning, please scroll down, unless you first want to deal with the PTSD of looking at the IPA.

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text:
â€œThought-Provokingâ€ (Confusing) Introduction
Previously, in orthographies, phonetics, and phonology, weâ€™ve discussed sounds and their symbols. Now, we take a step further into meaning.
Now, I want to emphasize that GENERALLY, sound and meaning are two separate things. This should make sense if you think about it - the meaning of â€œmeaningâ€ is just the idea tied to that word, and the sound is how that word is pronounced. There is nothing about the voiced bilabial nasal /m/ or the closed front unrounded vowel /i/ that makes the word â€œmeaningâ€ tied to the idea of â€œthe idea tied to that wordâ€. Note to reader: I do not apologize for provding confusing examples like this.
It may appear that there are exceptions. For example, the â€œwhâ€ in English commonly indicates an interrogative word, like the five that are commonly referenced - â€œwhoâ€, â€œwhatâ€, â€œwhyâ€, â€œwhereâ€, â€œwhenâ€. However, thereâ€™s nothing about the labiovelar approximant that is inherently tied to interrogative words. Instead, that was just an arbitrary sound that happened to evolve this way. Instead of calling the â€œwâ€ and the â€œhâ€ as phonemes, we would call â€œwhâ€ a unit that evolved out of a morpheme.
A morpheme is loosely defined as a unit of meaning. You may wonder why we do not just use the term â€œwordsâ€ to describe these. The answer is that â€œwordsâ€ are quite hard to define - I mean, an app like Word or Google Docs might just measure the number of spaces and then add one, because thatâ€™s generally convenient in English, but what about something like Mandarin? Would every sentence in Mandarin be a single â€œwordâ€ because there arenâ€™t any spaces? Such a question isnâ€™t easy or even helpful. Therefore, we use morphemes instead.
Since sound and meaning are independent, if your English teacher ever uses something like alliteration or rhyme to analyze a literary text, now you know that such an analysis is completely bogus. However, another possiblity also exists - your teacher is imagining how that sound is pronounced, and the manner and difficulty could add some â€œinsightfulâ€ meaning (by which I mean that itâ€™s definitely not intended to be that deep, and any such annotation is surely a stretch).

title: Cool Linguistics Stuff
text:
Types of Morphology Across Languages
There are two continuums that determine how a languageâ€™s morphology works. The first measures how many morphemes are squished into a single word, and the second measures how clearly morphemes are separated.
The first continuum ranges from one morpheme per word to multiple morphemes put together in a word to entire sentences fit in a word. In that order, the types of languages would be analytic, synthetic, and polysynthetic. Analyitic languages would be something like Mandarin - the sentence â€œI donâ€™t drink teaâ€ would be â€œæˆ‘ä¸å–èŒ¶â€ (â€œWÇ’ bÃ¹ hÄ“ chÃ¡â€). Each word is its own morpheme here. Purely analytic languages donâ€™t rely on inflection, or altering the form of words - instead, they rely on particles, which are words that are put next to other words to change the grammatical meaning. Synthetic languages actually inflect more and rely less on particles. For example, Latin uses verb conjugations and noun declensions to reflect gender, number, case, person, and more. As a result, it doesnâ€™t use articles, pronouns are optional, and there are less words in general. However, the entire sentence doesnâ€™t get smushed together, and you can still tell apart subjects, verbs, and objects. Polysynthetic languages are like an extreme form of regular synthetic languages.

title: Kinematics
text:
In circular motion, an object travels at a constant SPEED (let it be called \(v\)) in a circle. However, of course velocity changes, because itâ€™s always pointing in a different direction.  From here, we can introduce some new variables to reflect this motion. First, \(R\) is the radius of the circle. \(T\), the period, is defined as the amount of time it takes to make one full rotation, with units of seconds. \(f\), frequency, is the reciprocal of period, so itâ€™s the amount of rotations per second, with units of inverse seconds, or Hertz (Hz).
\(\omega\) is the angular velocity, which is how many radians travelled in a second. This means that \(\omega = 2 \pi / T\). Now, think about this. \(v\) is just the total distance over time, so \(v = 2 \pi R / T\). Look! This means that \(v = r \omega\)! Now, you may be wondering something. We may know the speed, but there MUST be acceleration! Otherwise, how can the velocity change? The vector for v is \([\omega r cos(\theta), \omega r sin(\theta)]\). These are just the horizontal and vertical components, with the magnitude being \(\omega r\). We want to find \(a = \frac{dv}{dt}\). We can get this from the Chain Rule, by computing \(\frac{dv}{d\theta} \cdot \frac{d\theta}{dt}\). \(\frac{dv}{d\theta}\) is going to be \([-\omega r sin(\theta), \omega r cos(\theta)]\). Meanwhile, \(\frac{d\theta}{dt}\) is just \(\omega\), by definition. So, multiplying these, we get \(\frac{dv}{dt} = [-\omega^2 r sin(\theta), \omega^2 r cos(\theta)]\). The magnitude of this acceleration is just \(\omega^2 r\), and the direction is pointed towards the center. (Explanation of that second part: The angles of the components of the velocity were with \(cos\) and \(sin\), so this means \(-sin\) and \(cos\) would be perpendicular to that, and more specifically towards the center, if cos and sin were tangent to the circle, which they are.) # Dynamics # Energy # Oscillations
